summary.summaryeli15:
Certainly! Sometimes it can be difficult to understand complex concepts, so I'll do my best to explain it in a simpler way.

Imagine you have a big problem that you need to solve, but it's really hard to figure out the solution. Sometimes when we face such problems, it helps to break them down into smaller, more manageable pieces. This is known as "divide and conquer."

By dividing the problem into smaller parts, it becomes easier to handle and solve each part separately. Once all the smaller parts are solved, we can then put them back together to find the solution for the entire problem.

This approach works because tackling smaller, easier problems reduces the complexity and makes it easier for our brain to process the information. It's like breaking a big task into smaller tasks, which allows us to focus on one thing at a time without feeling overwhelmed.

By breaking down the problem and solving each part individually, we gain a better understanding of the whole problem and find possible solutions more efficiently. So, instead of feeling stuck with a huge and daunting problem, dividing it into smaller, more manageable parts helps make it easier to solve!

summary.summary:
This is an email message from Michael Ford on May 26, 2023, regarding the release of Bitcoin Core version v25.0. In the email, Michael provides a link to download the software and mentions that it includes Antoine Riard's full-rbf peering code with some minor updates.

The full-rbf feature in this version of Bitcoin Core does two things for nodes that enable it:

1) Advertises a FULL_RBF service bit when mempoolfullrbf=1 is set. This means that the node supports full-replace-by-fee (RBF) transactions, which allows users to replace their existing transactions with fee adjustments.

2) Connects to four additional FULL_RBF peers. By doing this, a core group of nodes is established to reliably propagate full-rbf replacements.

The email emphasizes that it's not necessary for everyone to run this version, but it would be helpful if more people did. This is followed by a link to a blog post by Peter Todd, explaining the reasons why running mempoolfullrbf (full-rbf) is beneficial.

At the end of the email, a link to a tweet is provided, where it seems that Peter Todd has shared an image of hats related to this update.
summary.summaryeli15:
This email is announcing the release of Bitcoin Core version v25.0. Bitcoin Core is a software that helps run the Bitcoin network. This new version includes a feature called full-rbf peering code developed by Antoine Riard, along with some other small updates. 

The full-rbf peering code does two main things for nodes that enable it. Firstly, it advertises a service bit called FULL_RBF when a certain setting (mempoolfullrbf=1) is enabled. This helps other nodes know that this specific Bitcoin Core version supports full replace-by-fee (RBF) transactions. 

Secondly, it connects to four additional nodes that also support full RBF functionality. By doing this, it helps create a core group of nodes that can reliably propagate and communicate full-rbf replacements. This is important for ensuring that RBF transactions are properly propagated on the network. 

It is not necessary for everyone to run this specific version, but it would be helpful if more people did. The email also mentions a blog post that explains why running full-rbf can be beneficial. Additionally, there is a link to a tweet showing hats related to this release. 

Overall, this email is just an announcement about a new version of Bitcoin Core that includes a feature called full-rbf, which helps improve RBF transaction propagation on the network.
summary.title: Full-RBF Peering Bitcoin Core v25.0 Released

summary.summary: This message is an announcement from the LNP/BP Standards Association regarding the release of the RGB smart contract system. In the previous discussions, the association mentioned that introducing client-side validation has the potential to upgrade the Bitcoin layer 1 blockchain, which has been causing scaling and privacy issues. They now present Prime, a proposal to upgrade the Bitcoin protocol with a new layer 1 that is scalable and fully anonymous. This upgrade moves most of the validation work into the client-side validation system, while keeping Bitcoin as money and the rest of the ecosystem intact. The proposal doesn't require a softfork or miners' upgrade, but it can benefit from it. Users who choose not to upgrade are not affected, and consensus or majority is not required for the initial deployment. The upgrade also makes Lightning Network and other layer 2 systems redundant. Additionally, it will make certain features like BRC20, inscriptions, and ordinals impossible, and instead promotes the use of RGB smart contracts for proper assets and NFTs. The white paper detailing the proposal can be found on their GitHub page. The association is forming a working group to focus on the specification and implementation of this new layer and welcomes cooperation from anyone interested. They also plan to conduct educational and workshop activities to promote better understanding of the technology and informed decision-making. They emphasize that this effort should be funded through non-profit donations and will be launching a fundraising campaign. Interested individuals can contact them for more information.
summary.summaryeli15:
Dear community,

A while ago, the LNP/BP Standards Association announced the release of the RGB smart contract system. This system has the potential to upgrade the Bitcoin blockchain, which has been causing problems with scalability and privacy. The upgrade involves introducing client-side validation, which can be implemented more efficiently than the current Bitcoin blockchain. This proposal, called Prime, aims to create a new scalable and fully anonymous layer for Bitcoin, allowing for billions of transactions per minute. Importantly, it doesn't affect those who choose not to upgrade.

Prime also renders other systems like the Lightning Network redundant. It eliminates the need for certain features like BRC20, inscriptions, and ordinals, which will be replaced by RGB smart contracts. This means that non-users won't have to store, validate, or use their network bandwidth for third-party interests without compensation.

The white paper detailing the Prime proposal can be found at the provided link. The LNP/BP Standards Association is forming a working group to develop a formal specification and reference implementation for this new layer. They welcome anyone interested in collaborating on this project.

In terms of funding, the Association believes that this effort should be supported through non-profit donations rather than being managed by a for-profit company. They intend to launch a fundraising campaign and encourage anyone interested in driving Bitcoin's evolution to contact them.

For-profit organizations can also become members of the Association and contribute to shaping the future of Bitcoin technologies.

Thank you,
Dr. Maxim Orlovsky on behalf of LNP/BP Standards Association
summary.title: Scaling and anonymizing Bitcoin at layer 1 with client-side validation

In this text, the author is discussing the current status of the taproot annex, which is considered valid but non-standard in consensus. The conversations around standardization are leaning towards adopting a flexible Type-Length-Value (TLV) format. However, agreeing on an exact format may take a significant amount of time. 

In the meantime, the author suggests making the annex available in a non-structured form. This would allow developers to start using the taproot annex immediately, without the need to wait for the finalization of a more lengthy standardization process. 

The author proposes that any annex starting with '0' be considered free-form, without any additional constraints. This approach offers immediate utilization for developers and keeps options open for future developments and improvements in structure. 

There are several benefits to this strategy. It allows for immediate utilization of the taproot annex, future flexibility in terms of structure, and potential efficiency in terms of data size compared to a probable TLV format.

The author concludes that adopting this approach would broaden the utilization scope of the taproot annex while still allowing for a future transition to a more structured format. They believe this is a pragmatic and efficient route with significant benefits in both the short and long term.

The text also includes a reference to a GitHub pull request that provides further information on the topic.

summary.summary: The author is presenting an idea for a workaround in the situation where a parent transaction (Transaction A) and a fee bumping child transaction (Transaction B) cannot reach miners. They suggest introducing a third transaction (Transaction C) that contains both Transaction A and Transaction B. Transaction C would have sufficient fees and use at least one of the same fee contributing inputs as Transaction B. Miners, upon receiving Transaction C, would detect the embedded transactions A and B and immediately submit them to their mempool as a transaction package (A+B). This package, consisting of Transaction A and Transaction B, would then replace Transaction C and can be included in a block for mining. The author notes that it is important to ensure that the combined package of A+B is more attractive to miners than Transaction C. They also mention that there might be no extra costs associated with this package relay scheme unless the weight of A+B is very low and B needs to pay a higher fee rate than necessary. If not all miners adopt this replacement approach, there is a chance that Transaction C ends up being mined. However, the author suggests that this is less probable if the fee rate for C is kept to a minimum. If Transaction C is indeed mined, the process can be retried with modified B and C transactions, but the fees paid for the initial transaction C would be forfeited.
summary.summaryeli15:
The idea I am going to explain is not something I necessarily support, but it's interesting to discuss. Currently, there is a situation where a transaction, let's call it A, is not reaching miners because it has a very low fee. There is another transaction, B, that could bump up the fee of A, but it also cannot reach miners. So, to find a solution, we introduce a third transaction, C.

Transaction C is created to contain both transactions A and B. To ensure that transaction C gets propagated, it would pay sufficient fees and use at least one of the same fee-contributing inputs as transaction B. Miners, when they receive transaction C, would detect the embedded transactions A and B, and immediately submit them to their mempool as a transaction package. This transaction package (A+B) would then replace transaction C and could be included in a block for mining.

It is important to ensure that the combined package of A+B is more attractive to miners than transaction C. The weight of the embedded transactions in C helps with this. Also, the fees for transaction C will never be paid because it has been replaced. So, there are no extra costs for using this package relay scheme, unless the weight of A+B is very low and B needs to pay a higher fee rate than necessary to ensure the replacement of C.

If not all miners adopt this replacement scheme, there is a chance transaction C ends up being mined. However, this is less likely if the fee rate for C is kept to a minimum. If transaction C is indeed mined, the operation can be retried with modified versions of transactions B and C, but the fees paid for the initial transaction C would be forfeited.

I hope this explanation makes sense!
summary.title: Conceptual package relay using taproot annex

summary.summary:
The text you provided is an announcement and overview of a proposal called "Silent Payments." This proposal aims to address privacy concerns in Bitcoin transactions by eliminating the need for interaction between sender and receiver, eliminating the need for notifications, and protecting the privacy of both sender and receiver.

Currently, in order to maintain privacy, it is recommended to use a new address for each Bitcoin transaction. This requires secure interaction between the sender and receiver to exchange addresses or generate addresses on-demand. However, this interaction is often infeasible or undesirable.

To solve this problem, various protocols have been proposed that use a static payment address and notifications sent via the blockchain. These protocols eliminate the need for interaction but come with increased costs and reveal metadata about the sender and receiver.

The Silent Payments proposal aims to eliminate the need for interaction and notifications while still maintaining privacy. The proposal suggests a protocol where each transaction goes to a unique address, avoiding accidental address reuse. It also supports payment labeling, uses existing seed phrase or descriptor methods for backup and recovery, and separates scanning and spending responsibilities.

While this proposal provides significant benefits for privacy, it does require wallets to scan the blockchain to detect payments, which can pose a challenge for lightweight clients. Light client support is considered an area of ongoing research.

The overview provides a high-level description of the protocol, including how a silent payment address is created, how multiple outputs can be created, how address reuse is prevented, and how all inputs can be used in a transaction. It also discusses the concept of spend and scan keys, labels for payments, and labels for change outputs.

The proposal concludes by stating its goals, including no increase in the size or cost of transactions, blending in with other Bitcoin transactions, protecting anonymity, not requiring sender-receiver interaction, not linking multiple payments, supporting payment labeling, and being compatible with other spending protocols. It also mentions that the protocol is upgradeable and supports light client/SPV wallet.

Overall, the Silent Payments proposal aims to enhance privacy in Bitcoin transactions by providing a protocol that eliminates the need for interaction and notifications while maintaining anonymity and protecting sender and receiver privacy.
summary.summaryeli15:

In the current Bitcoin system, using a new address for each transaction is important for privacy. However, this often requires communication between the sender and receiver to generate a fresh address. Silent Payments proposes a solution that doesn't require this interaction.

One approach that has been used is using a static payment address and notifications sent through the blockchain. However, this increases costs and can reveal information about the sender and receiver.

The Silent Payments proposal addresses these limitations by eliminating the need for interaction and notifications, while protecting the privacy of both parties. This is done by having wallets scan the blockchain to detect payments, instead of relying on sender-receiver communication. However, this can be challenging for light clients.

The goals of this proposal include not increasing transaction size or cost, making resulting transactions indistinguishable from other Bitcoin transactions, preventing the link between transactions and silent payment addresses from being seen by others, and more.

The protocol works by creating a silent payment address and using a hash function to generate a unique output for each transaction. Additional features are included to prevent address reuse, support payment labeling, and ensure compatibility with other spending protocols.

Overall, Silent Payments aims to improve privacy and security in Bitcoin transactions by eliminating the need for interaction, notifications, and preserving the privacy of both the sender and receiver.
summary.title: BIP for Silent Payments

summary.summary: I'm sorry, but you haven't provided any specific information or context to explain. Can you please provide more details or clarify your question?
summary.summaryeli15:
Of course! I'd be happy to explain it to you like you're 15.

The internet is a huge network that connects computers and devices all around the world. When you browse the internet, you use a web browser (like Google Chrome or Safari) to access websites, watch videos, chat with friends, and more.

When you type a website address into the address bar (like www.youtube.com), your browser sends a request to a server, which is basically a powerful computer that stores and delivers the website's files. The server sends those files back to your browser, and it interprets and displays them as a webpage.

The process of sending and receiving these files is called data transfer. To send and receive data, you need an internet connection, which could be wired (like through an Ethernet cable) or wireless (like through Wi-Fi).

The websites you visit are stored on servers owned by companies or individuals. These servers hold the website's files, such as text, images, videos, and code. When you visit a website, your browser downloads these files and displays them so you can interact with the website.

Websites are created using a combination of different programming languages, such as HTML, CSS, and JavaScript. These languages allow developers to design and structure webpages, make them look good, and add interactivity.

Many websites also make use of databases to store and retrieve information. For example, when you create an account on a website, your information is stored in a database. When you log in later, the website checks the database to verify your credentials.

To protect the data you send and receive online, websites use different security measures. You'll often see a little lock icon in the address bar when you visit a website. This indicates that the website is using encryption to secure your data during transmission.

Overall, the internet is a vast network that allows you to explore and access a wide range of information and services. It connects us all and enables communication, entertainment, education, and much more.

summary.summary:
In this message, ThomasV is proposing an extension to BOLT-11, which is a specification for Lightning Network invoices. The proposed extension would allow invoices to contain two bundled payments, each with distinct preimages (unique codes) and amounts.

The motivation for this extension is to address the specific use case of services that require prepayment of a mining fee for certain transactions to take place. These services include submarine swaps and JIT (Just-In-Time) channels.

In submarine swaps, the service provider receives a Hashed Time-Locked Contract (HTLC) for which they don't have the preimage (the code needed to claim the funds). They have to send funds on-chain and wait for the client to reveal the preimage when they claim the payment. To ensure they are compensated for the potential loss if the client doesn't claim the payment, the service providers ask for a prepayment.

However, some competitors of these services cannot ask for a prepayment because their software is not designed to handle it. For example, Boltz exchange shows an invoice to the user, but their wallet is agnostic about the swap, so it would be impractical to show two invoices to be paid simultaneously. This creates a vulnerability where these competitors can be targeted with Denial-of-Service (DoS) attacks that force them to pay on-chain fees.

In the case of JIT channels, providers who want to protect themselves against mining fee attacks need to ask for the preimage of the main payment before opening the channel. This, however, makes them custodians, which brings legal implications. European MICA regulation categorizes such services as custodian services. Competitors who refuse to offer custodian services are excluded from the market.

To address these issues, ThomasV suggests bundling the prepayment and the main payment in the same BOLT-11 invoice. The semantics of bundled payments would require the receiver to wait until all the HTLCs of both payments have arrived before fulfilling the HTLCs of the prepayment. If the main payment does not arrive, the prepayment should fail with a MPP (Multi-Path Payments) timeout. Once both payments have arrived, the receiver fulfills the prepayment HTLCs and broadcasts the on-chain transaction. It is important to note that the main payment can still fail if the sender never reveals the preimage.

ThomasV acknowledges that this proposal does not solve the issue of potential prepayment theft by the service provider, but states that this is an existing risk. The proposed change aims to level the playing field among lightning service providers and would also benefit ACINQ, making their pay-to-open service fully non-custodian.

Finally, ThomasV suggests implementing this change in BOLT-11 rather than introducing new specifications like BOLT-12 or onion messages. He argues that non-interactive solutions should be prioritized over adding new message exchange protocols.
summary.summaryeli15:
Good morning! So, basically, this person named ThomasV wants to suggest a change to something called BOLT-11. BOLT-11 is like a format or standard for invoices in a system called Lightning Network, which is used for making payments with cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin. 

ThomasV's proposal is to allow invoices to have two payments bundled together. This would be useful for certain services that require a prepayment before they can make a transaction. For example, let's say you want to use a service called "submarine swaps" or "JIT channels". These services involve a situation where the service provider receives a payment but doesn't have all the necessary information to complete the transaction yet. They have to wait for the customer to provide some special code or "preimage" to unlock the payment.

But here's the problem: there's no guarantee that the customer will actually provide the preimage and claim the payment. So, in order to protect themselves, the service providers ask for a prepayment to cover any potential costs they might have to pay, like mining fees for example. 

However, some service providers have dedicated software that can handle this situation, so they can ask for the prepayment. But others, like the Boltz exchange, don't have that kind of software and it would be difficult for them to ask for two separate payments from the customer. This makes them vulnerable to something called a Denial of Service (DoS) attack, where someone could force them to pay extra fees. 

Another issue is that if a service provider asks for the preimage before opening a channel, they become what's called a "custodian" of the funds. This has legal implications and falls under certain regulations.

ThomasV's idea is to solve these problems by allowing the prepayment and the main payment to be bundled together in the same invoice. The receiver of the payment would then wait for both payments to arrive before fulfilling the prepayment part. If the main payment doesn't arrive, they would fail the prepayment part. Once both payments are received, the receiver fulfills the prepayment and makes the transaction.

Of course, it's still possible for the service provider to steal the prepayment, but that's already a risk with the current system. The goal of this proposal is to create a fair competition between different lightning service providers and make it easier for them to offer their services without becoming custodians.

ThomasV believes this change should be implemented in BOLT-11 itself, the existing system, rather than creating a new system. They think the change can be done without adding new messages or making things more complicated.

I hope that explanation makes sense to you! Let me know if you have any more questions.

- The Bitcoin Core PR Review Club is a monthly club that meets on the first Wednesday and Thursday of each month.
- It is held on the #bitcoin-core-pr-reviews IRC channel on libera.chat.
- The purpose of the club is to help newer contributors learn about the Bitcoin Core codebase and review process.
- The focus is on learning and understanding the codebase and review process, rather than getting PRs merged.
- Anyone who wants to learn about contributing to Bitcoin Core is welcome to participate and ask questions.
- Participants benefit by gaining knowledge and tools to contribute to the Bitcoin Core review process on GitHub.
- To participate, one just needs to show up on IRC. More tips on participation can be found on the website.
- Upcoming meetings are scheduled by glozow and stickies-v, and the meetings are hosted by various Bitcoin Core contributors.
- The club is always looking for interesting PRs to discuss and volunteer hosts to lead the discussions.

summary.summary:
The PR (Pull Request) is introducing changes to the transaction states and conflict handling in Bitcoin Core's wallet. Previously, only transactions conflicted by being included in a mined block were considered conflicted, while transactions conflicting with mempool transactions were treated as inactive. This could cause confusion for users as their funds would briefly appear to disappear. This PR aims to treat mempool-conflicted transactions as conflicted as well.

The PR is fixing a bug where mempool-conflicted transactions were not properly treated as conflicts and adding a feature to improve user experience and clarity.

The trade-off of considering mempool-conflicted transactions as conflicted instead of inactive is that the wallet will accurately reflect the state of the transaction immediately, reducing confusion for users. However, this may also result in more transactions being marked as conflicted, potentially impacting performance and requiring users to wait longer for their transactions to be confirmed.

The first commit is necessary as it introduces the new transaction state (TxStateMempoolConflicted) and modifies the handling of conflicted transactions.

The MempoolConflicts map is added to keep track of conflicting transactions in the mempool. This allows the wallet to easily access and analyze the conflicting transactions without having to check each individual transaction in the mempool.

Adding another transaction state (TxStateMempoolConflicted) instead of just using TxStateConflicted allows for clearer differentiation between conflicts originating from the mempool and conflicts originating from mined blocks.

With this PR, a user should be able to abandon a transaction with a mempool conflict. The changes made in the PR enable the wallet to properly handle abandoned transactions with mempool conflicts.

After a wallet is reloaded, a previously mempool-conflicted transaction will retain its transaction state of TxStateMempoolConflicted.

The tests added in wallet_conflicts.py should not fail on master.

The changes made in this PR do not directly modify the balance calculation code. However, by accurately reflecting the transaction states and conflicts, the changes indirectly affect the balance calculation of the wallet as it ensures that transactions are properly accounted for.

TxStateConflicted and TxStateMempoolConflicted transactions are treated differently in memory. The addition of TxStateMempoolConflicted allows for a more accurate representation and handling of mempool conflicts.

There may be additional test cases that could be implemented to further validate and verify the changes introduced in this PR, but it depends on the specific requirements and considerations of the Bitcoin Core development team.

wallet_abandonconflict.py needs to be modified in the second commit to ensure it properly handles abandoning transactions with mempool conflicts. The changes made in the PR affect the conflict handling logic, so it is necessary to update the relevant test case accordingly.
summary.summaryeli15:
PR stands for Pull Request, which is a way for developers to propose changes to a software project. In this instance, the PR is related to Bitcoin Core, a popular cryptocurrency software. 

The PR is addressing an issue with how the wallet handles transaction conflicts. When two transactions conflict with each other, the wallet needs to decide how to handle them. Previously, if a transaction conflict only occurred in the mempool (the pool of unconfirmed transactions), the wallet would consider it as inactive rather than conflicted. This caused confusion for users because it appeared as if their funds had temporarily disappeared.

This PR introduces a new transaction state called "TxStateMempoolConflicted" to handle transactions in the mempool that have conflicts. It also adds a map called "MempoolConflicts" to keep track of the conflicting transactions. By doing this, the wallet will now treat mempool-conflicted transactions as conflicted, providing a clearer view for users. 

The PR does not fix a bug, but rather adds a feature to improve user experience and prevent confusion. 

One trade-off of considering a mempool-conflicted transaction as conflicted instead of inactive is that it may lead to some delays in transactions being considered spendable. This is because the wallet will need to wait until the conflicting transaction is mined into a block before it can mark the mempool-conflicted transaction as spendable. 

The first commit of the PR is necessary as it introduces the new transaction state and adds the MempoolConflicts map. This commit does not change any existing behavior. 

The MempoolConflicts map is added to make it easier for the wallet to keep track of conflicting transactions. Without this map, the wallet would need to check for conflicts by scanning through all the transactions, which may not be efficient. 

Adding the TxStateMempoolConflicted transaction state provides a more accurate representation of the transaction's status. By having a separate state for mempool conflicts, it allows the wallet to differentiate between conflicts in the mempool and conflicts in mined blocks. 

With this PR, a user will be able to abandon a transaction that has a mempool conflict. This means they can choose to not proceed with the transaction and regain control over the funds involved. 

After a wallet is reloaded, a previously mempool-conflicted transaction will still be marked as mempool-conflicted. The status of the transaction is persistent, even after reloading the wallet. 

The tests added in wallet_conflicts.py do not fail on the current version of the software (referred to as "master"). 

Although the PR does not directly modify the balance calculation code, the changes made impact the balance calculation indirectly. By treating mempool-conflicted transactions as conflicted, the wallet will exclude these transactions from the balance calculation. This ensures that the balance accurately reflects the spendable funds. 

TxStateConflicted and TxStateMempoolConflicted transactions are not treated the same in memory. They have different transaction states, which allows the wallet to handle them differently based on their status. 

There may be additional test cases that could be implemented to further test the changes made in this PR. This would help ensure that the new functionality works correctly in all scenarios. 

The wallet_abandonconflict.py file needs to be modified in the second commit because it is related to transaction abandonment. The changes made in this commit likely address how the wallet handles abandoning transactions that have mempool conflicts.

This paragraph is discussing a code review for a Pull Request (PR) in the software project Bitcoin Core. The PR, which follows PR 25325, is being reviewed in a review club meeting. The PR introduces changes related to the -dbcache configuration option, which determines the amount of memory used for the coins cache and other database uses of memory.

The paragraph explains that using less memory than allowed for the cache decreases the cache hit ratio, while using more memory than specified can cause crashes on memory-restricted systems. Therefore, it is important to have an accurate accounting of the memory used by the cache.

When a program requests a certain amount of dynamic memory, it actually allocates slightly more due to overhead metadata. The memory allocator metadata is complex and varies depending on factors like machine architecture and memory model. In order to accurately size the cache, the logical memory size needs to be converted to physical memory size, but there is no library function available for this conversion.

To solve this, Bitcoin Core includes the function MallocUsage() that approximates the conversion. The source file memusage.h contains various overloads of the function DynamicUsage() for different data types. These overloads use MallocUsage() to calculate the physical memory size.

The PR being reviewed adds a new overload of DynamicUsage() for the pool memory resource, which computes the overall coins cache size. The overload is called only from CCoinsViewCache::DynamicMemoryUsage(). The purpose of the review is to provide feedback on the PR and its approach.

In the master branch (without this PR), the DynamicUsage() overload has many templated arguments to handle different types of memory allocations. Comparing it to the overload immediately above it (line 170), we can understand the need for the different template arguments.

The DynamicUsage() overload on the master branch adds various values together to calculate the memory usage. In this PR, the DynamicUsage() calculation is moved to a different location, and the m.bucket_count() is no longer needed. This change has the advantage of not referencing m.bucket_count(), simplifying the calculation. However, it is not explicitly mentioned where the DynamicUsage() calculation is moved to in this PR.

The extra credit question references cachedCoinsUsage as a variable and asks why it is added to memusage::DynamicUsage(cacheCoins()) in CCoinsViewCache::DynamicMemoryUsage(). Unfortunately, the context surrounding cachedCoinsUsage and where it is referenced is not provided in the given paragraph, so it is not possible to answer this question accurately.

Of course! I'll explain it in a way that is easier to understand for someone who is 15.

When you interact with the internet, you may have noticed that sometimes you need to confirm that you're not a robot by completing a task like selecting all the images with cars or typing in a series of distorted words. This is known as a CAPTCHA.

CAPTCHA stands for 'Completely Automated Public Turing test to tell Computers and Humans Apart.' In simpler terms, it's a way to check if you're a real human or a computer program trying to access a website or perform certain actions.

The purpose of CAPTCHA is to protect websites from automated bots that could potentially spam or harm them. Without a CAPTCHA, a malicious program could repeatedly submit forms, create fake accounts, or overload a website's server, causing trouble and inconvenience for the site's owners and users.

When you encounter a CAPTCHA, the task it asks you to complete is designed to be easy for a human to understand but challenging for computers. For example, it might ask you to click on all the images that show a traffic light. While humans can easily tell which images have traffic lights, it's much harder for a computer program to do so accurately. By successfully completing the CAPTCHA, you're proving that you're human and not a bot.

CAPTCHAs have become common on the internet as a way to maintain security and protect websites from automated attacks. They help ensure that users are genuine humans and not automated programs, ultimately ensuring a safer and better online experience for everyone.

In this week's newsletter, there are several topics discussed. 

Firstly, there is a proposal to extend BOLT11 invoices, which are used in the Lightning Network, to allow a receiver to request two separate payments from a spender. Each payment would have a separate secret and amount. This could be useful for submarine swaps and JIT (Just-In-Time) channels. However, there is ongoing discussion about this proposal, with some concerns raised about practicality and compatibility with existing implementations.

Secondly, there is a limited weekly series about mempool policy, which is the policy that determines which transactions get included in the mempool (the pool of pending transactions) and ultimately confirmed by miners. The series explores the reasons behind the current policy used by Bitcoin Core and how wallets can use that policy effectively.

This includes the announcement of Greenlight libraries being open sourced, a tapscript debugger called Tapsim, the release of Bitcoin Keeper 1.0.4 with coinjoin support, the announcement of the Lightning wallet EttaWallet, a proof-of-concept for zkSNARK-based block header sync, and the release of lnprototest v0.0.4, a test suite for the Lightning Network.

Lastly, there are updates and release candidates for various Bitcoin infrastructure projects, including Bitcoin Core, Core Lightning, Eclair, LDK, LND, libsecp256k1, Hardware Wallet Interface (HWI), Rust Bitcoin, BTCPay Server, BDK, Bitcoin Improvement Proposals (BIPs), Lightning BOLTs, and Bitcoin Inquisition. summary.summaryeli15:
This week's newsletter covers a few topics related to Bitcoin. 
First, it talks about an idea for preventing the pinning of coinjoin transactions. Coinjoin is a method of combining multiple Bitcoin transactions into one, making it difficult to trace the individual transactions. However, there is a concern that someone participating in a coinjoin transaction could create a conflicting transaction that prevents the coinjoin transaction from being confirmed. The proposed solution is to have each participant in a coinjoin transaction initially spend their bitcoins to a script that can only be spent either by a signature from all participants or by just the participant after a certain amount of time has passed.

The newsletter also discusses a proposal for using hoped-for consensus changes. Consensus rules are the rules that all Bitcoin participants must agree on for transactions to be valid. The proposal suggests that if certain changes to the consensus rules are made, it could benefit some users who receive Bitcoin on another chain. These users would then have an incentive to advocate for the changes, but this could make other users feel coerced or manipulated.

Additionally, the newsletter includes a section on mempool policy. The mempool is where pending Bitcoin transactions are stored before they are confirmed and added to the blockchain. The policy for including transactions in the mempool can affect the scalability and accessibility of the Bitcoin network. The newsletter discusses the importance of protecting shared network resources and finding a balance between network growth and limiting block sizes to keep running a Bitcoin node affordable.

The newsletter also includes popular questions and answers from the Bitcoin Stack Exchange, highlights new releases and changes to popular Bitcoin infrastructure software, and mentions projects that help Bitcoin-based businesses integrate scaling technology.

summary.summary:
This update is discussing a recent exploit in a lending protocol called Atlantis Loans on the Binance Smart Chain (BSC). The developers of Atlantis Loans abandoned the platform in April, citing financial constraints. However, the protocol remained active with its user interface paid up in advance for two years. 

On June 7th, an attacker pushed and voted through a governance proposal, granting them control over Atlantis Loans' token contracts. They then upgraded the contracts with their own malicious code, allowing them to transfer tokens from any address that still had active approvals to Atlantis contracts. As a result, funds were drained from former users, totaling approximately $1 million. 

This incident highlights the vulnerability of abandoned projects and the importance of monitoring governance processes, even for defunct projects. It also serves as a reminder for users to revoke old token approvals and stay vigilant against potential attacks. 

The update also mentions similar governance attacks in the past, such as the Tornado Cash and Beanstalk incidents, emphasizing the need for caution and security in decentralized finance (DeFi) projects. Additionally, it briefly mentions other recent losses in Midas and Safemoon due to vulnerabilities and bugs in their systems.
summary.summaryeli15:
In simpler terms, here's what happened:

Atlantis Loans was a lending program on the Binance Smart Chain. The developers of the program abandoned it in April because they couldn't afford to continue maintaining it. They made a post on Medium to inform users about this decision.

However, even though the developers stopped working on the program, it remained active. The attacker took advantage of this and used a trick called a "governance attack" to gain control of Atlantis Loans' token contracts. They then modified these contracts to be able to transfer tokens from any active user's address to the attacker's address.

The initial attempt to attack Atlantis Loans failed, but the attacker tried again and succeeded by pushing through a governance proposal. This allowed them to take control and steal funds from users of the program.

This incident serves as a reminder to revoke old token approvals and highlights the importance of carefully monitoring governance processes, even on projects that are no longer active.

In other news, other platforms like Midas, Level Finance, and Safemoon also experienced security vulnerabilities or attacks, resulting in significant financial losses. These incidents show that weaknesses and vulnerabilities can quickly spread throughout the cryptocurrency ecosystem, and it's important for these platforms to learn from these mistakes and improve their security measures.
summary.title: Atlantis Loans hit by governance attack, drained of $2.5M

Natural language processing (NLP) is a branch of artificial intelligence (AI) that focuses on making computers understand and communicate with humans using natural language, like how you and I talk to each other. It's all about teaching computers how to understand, interpret, and generate human-like language.

NLP helps computers understand what we say or write, even if it's not perfectly structured or grammatically correct. This is important because human language is complex and can have different meanings depending on the context. For example, "I saw a bat" could mean a flying mammal or a wooden club used in sports. NLP helps computers figure out the right meaning by considering the surrounding words or sentences.

One of the key tasks in NLP is called sentiment analysis. It involves analyzing and understanding the emotions or opinions expressed in text, like social media posts or online reviews. Imagine you have thousands of tweets about a movie, and you want to know whether people liked it or not. NLP algorithms can analyze those tweets and give you an overall sentiment about the movie, like positive or negative.

Another task is machine translation, where NLP helps translate one language into another. This is useful for things like translating websites, apps, or documents. For example, if you want to read a news article in Spanish but don't speak the language, an NLP-powered translation system can quickly convert it into English for you.

NLP is also used in chatbots and virtual assistants, like Siri or Alexa. These AI systems are designed to have conversations with us, answer questions, and assist with tasks. They understand spoken or written input, process it using NLP techniques, and provide relevant responses.

Overall, NLP is all about enabling computers to understand human language in a more natural and meaningful way, allowing them to communicate, assist, and even emulate human-like conversations.

This passage is discussing various incidents of financial loss due to price manipulation exploits in different decentralized finance (DeFi) protocols.

The first incident mentioned is about Sturdy Finance, an Ethereum-based lending protocol. It experienced a price manipulation exploit that resulted in a loss of around $800k. The protocol allows yield farmers to deposit staked assets as collateral to leverage their yields.

The Sturdy Finance team acknowledged the attack and paused all markets to prevent further risk. They assured users that no additional funds were at risk and no user actions were required at the time of the statement.

The attack on Sturdy Finance was similar to previous exploits on Midas Capital and dForce Network, according to Ancilia (presumably a source or an expert).

In this attack, a flash loan was used to target the SturdyOracle, which is unfortunately named as it became the exploitation point. The attacker manipulated the price of the collateral token (B-stETH-STABLE) and made a profit of 442 ETH ($800k). The attacker then deposited the funds into Tornado Cash for laundering, completing the process within 20 minutes.

The vulnerability that allowed this attack, known as read-only reentrancy vulnerability, has been seen in several attacks over the past year. The vulnerability was also highlighted in a previous post on Balancer forums, indicating that some Balancer pools are susceptible to the same attack vector.

Despite Sturdy Finance having undergone three audits by Certik, Quantstamp, and Code4rena, the vulnerability was not detected and the pools were left open to attack. This raises concerns about the security of DeFi protocols and leads to discussions around the need for oracle-free lending systems.

The passage then briefly mentions other incidents of financial loss in different protocols. AlphaPo lost $60M and EraLend lost $3.4M to reentrancy bugs, while Conic Finance lost $4.2M from its pools. The repeated occurrence of such incidents highlights the need for stronger security measures in the crypto space.

Artificial intelligence, commonly known as AI, refers to the ability of a computer or machine to perform tasks that typically require human intelligence. It's like teaching a machine to think and learn on its own.

There are different types of AI. One type is called "narrow AI" which is designed to perform specific tasks really well. For example, voice assistants like Siri or Alexa use narrow AI to understand and respond to our commands.

On the other hand, there's "general AI" which is more like human intelligence. It can think, learn, and understand things just like us. However, we don't have this kind of AI yet, and scientists are still trying to develop it.

AI learns through a process called machine learning. It's like training a machine to learn from data and make predictions or decisions based on that data. For example, if you feed a lot of pictures of cats into an AI, it can learn to recognize cats in new pictures.

AI has many practical applications. It's used in things like self-driving cars, medical diagnosis, and even in video games to create realistic characters and behaviors.

However, AI also brings some challenges and concerns. One concern is that AI might take over jobs that are currently done by humans. Another concern is that AI can sometimes make mistakes or be biased if it's trained on biased data.

Overall, AI is an exciting field of technology that has the potential to greatly impact our lives, and it's constantly evolving with new advancements and discoveries.

Artificial intelligence (AI) refers to the ability of machines or computers to perform tasks that normally require human intelligence. It involves creating smart computer systems that can learn, reason, and solve problems on their own.

1. Narrow AI: This is AI designed to perform specific tasks, like voice recognition or image identification. Narrow AI is what you see in virtual assistants like Siri or Alexa. They are really good at a particular task but can't do anything else.

2. General AI: This is AI that can perform any intellectual task that a human being can do. It doesn't exist yet, but scientists and researchers are working towards developing machines that can think, reason, and replicate human intelligence.

3. Machine Learning: This is a subset of AI in which machines can learn from data and improve their performance over time without being explicitly programmed. For example, if you feed a machine learning algorithm thousands of cat pictures, it can learn to recognize cats in new pictures without explicitly being told what a cat looks like.

4. Deep Learning: This is a type of machine learning that uses artificial neural networks, similar to the human brain, to process and learn from large amounts of data. Deep learning is especially good at recognizing patterns and classifying things. It powers many AI applications, like facial recognition technology.

AI is used in various fields, like healthcare, finance, transportation, and entertainment. It can help doctors make accurate diagnoses, improve customer service through chatbots, enhance autonomous vehicles, and even create realistic video game characters.

While AI has many benefits, it also raises some concerns. Some people worry that AI could take away jobs or be used for malicious purposes. There are also ethical questions surrounding AI, such as privacy concerns and the potential for bias in decision-making. So, as AI continues to evolve, it's important to consider its advantages and challenges.
